item.title: My first basic calculator (just started coding)
item.dc:creator: @dain_bramage dain bramage
item.description:
@dain_bramage wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:4, topic:407042”][quote author=dain bramage link=topic=508338.msg3687721#msg3687721 date=1311946999]
Goodjob, I guess. I always use this, though (rather than a scanner):

public static String getUserInput() throws Exception { BufferedReader buf = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in)); return buf.readLine(); }
[/quote]

But that method, though perfectly valid, is terrible because every time that method is called (which probably will be pretty often) it will create new BufferReader and InputStreamReader instances. They only should be instaniated once![/quote]
My bad. Probably should have thought of that myself :P.

Read full topic
item.source: My first basic calculator (just started coding)

item.title: My first basic calculator (just started coding)
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

[quote=“dain bramage, post:3, topic:407042”]Goodjob, I guess. I always use this, though (rather than a scanner):

public static String getUserInput() throws Exception { BufferedReader buf = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in)); return buf.readLine(); }[/quote]

But that method, though perfectly valid, is terrible because every time that method is called (which probably will be pretty often) it will create new BufferReader and InputStreamReader instances. They only should be instaniated once!

@op: I understand this is probably one of your first programs, but you should really try a more function orientated approach instead of a procedural one (object orientatated would be a bit over the top for this program). Continue to learn about methods and it’ll make more sense.

Read full topic
item.source: My first basic calculator (just started coding)

item.title: My first basic calculator (just started coding)
item.dc:creator: @theowned theowned
item.description:
@theowned wrote:

hello moparscape theowned here i just started coding java this is my basic calculator

import java.util.Scanner;

public class Helloworld
{
public static void main( String[] args ){
Scanner hello = new Scanner (System.in);
double fnum,snum,answer;
System.out.println(“enter your first number”);
fnum = hello.nextDouble();
System.out.println(“enter your second number”);
snum = hello.nextDouble();
answer = fnum + snum;
System.out.print(“your answer is : “);
System.out.println(answer);
System.out.println(””);
System.out.println(“this calculator is created by theowned”);
System.out.println(“thanx for using”);

}

}

Read full topic
